title: What crimes is restorative justice used for? - Quora

response.answer_text: I've seen many crimes used, but it seems that the community, the news coverage and family rallying for justice plays a factor. I mean definitely you dont want to be a target of harrassment and your case/crime is personal and you have a right to do just your time, but that would not come within the confines of prison. Prison officials are not allowed to make an example of your crime, rather they have an obligation to your well being and saftey. That would be more tailored to Private groups, County or State officials, churches and so on, to decide which crime is put “on blast" and show that sentences should be stiffer on whatever it is they are rallying against, but Prison officials cannot do this

Restorative justice can be used for all crimes - except for the artificial ones that don’t even have victims. Making victims whole is the objective of restorative justice. Sometimes this involves interaction with the tortfeasor (debtor), but the victim needn’t be further burdened by anything that adds to his psychological or monetary loss. When another party steps in to help the victim recover losses or damages, a host of opportunities for settlement arise; investigation, bonding, collection, financing, publication, even job placement for debtors who are without means. Each case is unique. Instead of the victim having to pay for these services, the subrogating party pays him (or his estate) for the right to subrogate, and orchestrates a recoupment plan.
